Asturian

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Ecclesiastical Latin cōnfessāre.

Verb

[edit]

confesar (first-person singular indicative present confieso, past participle confesáu)

  1. to confess

Conjugation

[edit]
Conjugation of confesar
infinitive confesar
gerund confesando
past participle m confesáu, f confesada, n confesao, m pl confesaos, f pl confesaes

tu 		third singular

nosotros/nós 		second plural
vosotros/vós 		third plural
ellos
indicative present confieso confieses confiesa confesamos confesáis confiesen
imperfect confesaba confesabes confesaba confesábemos, confesábamos confesabeis, confesabais confesaben
preterite confesé confesasti, confesesti confesó confesemos confesastis, confesestis confesaron
pluperfect confesare, confesara confesares, confesaras confesare, confesara confesáremos, confesáramos confesareis, confesarais confesaren, confesaran
future confesaré confesarás confesará confesaremos confesaréis confesarán
conditional confesaría confesaríes confesaría confesaríemos, confesaríamos confesaríeis, confesaríais confesaríen
subjunctive present confiese confieses, confiesas confiese confesemos confeséis confiesen, confiesan
imperfect confesare, confesara confesares, confesaras confesare, confesara confesáremos, confesáramos confesareis, confesarais confesaren, confesaran
imperative — confiesa — — confesái —

Related terms

[edit]
  • confesión
  • confesor

Further reading

[edit]
  • “confesar”, in Diccionariu de la llingua asturiana [Dictionary of the Asturian Language] (in Asturian), 1ª edición, Academia de la Llingua Asturiana, 2000, →ISBN
  • Xosé Lluis García Arias (2002–2004), “confesar”, in Diccionario general de la lengua asturiana [General Dictionary of the Asturian Language] (in Spanish), Editorial Prensa Asturiana, →ISBN

Galician

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • confessar (reintegrationist)

Etymology

[edit]

From Ecclesiastical Latin cōnfessāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
This entry needs pronunciation information. If you are familiar with the IPA then please add some!

Verb

[edit]

confesar (first-person singular present confeso, first-person singular preterite confesei, past participle confesado)

  1. to confess

Romanian

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin confessarius.

Noun

[edit]

confesar m (plural confesari)

  1. (obsolete) confessor
    Synonym: confesor

Declension

[edit]
singular plural
indefinite definite indefinite definite
nominative-accusative confesar confesarul confesari confesarii
genitive-dative confesar confesarului confesari confesarilor
vocative confesarule confesarilor

References

[edit]
  • confesar in Academia Română, Micul dicționar academic, ediția a II-a, Bucharest: Univers Enciclopedic, 2010. →ISBN

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Ecclesiastical Latin cōnfessāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /konfeˈsaɾ/ [kõɱ.feˈsaɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: con‧fe‧sar

Verb

[edit]

confesar (first-person singular present confieso, first-person singular preterite confesé, past participle confesado)

  1. (transitive) to confess, to come clean about
  2. (intransitive) to confess, to come clean
  3. (Christianity) to hear confession

Conjugation

[edit]

1Mostly obsolete, now mainly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tú form for the present subjunctive.
